subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: ... If you look up arrest and arrive on dictinary.com, you find /əˈrɛst/ and  /əˈraɪv/. My Longman s dictioanry lists them the same way. So you read
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Ah, comprehension dawns! This is an absolute non-issue for you, and by
> extension for many others on this list!
>
> For those of us who have to backtrack once we're halfway through a
> word, realizing that we have to replace /3\/ with /Vr\/ in order to
> correctly read the word--I guess we just have to acclimatize to the
> notation.
>

If you look up "arrest" and "arrive" on dictinary.com, you find /əˈrɛst/
and /əˈraɪv/. My Longman's dictioanry lists them the same way. So you
read these words the way most Americans do, and I
would guess most other English speakers do. There is no r-colored /@/,
or /3/. That means we do indeed need to show that Ado Roar in these
cases must be read as first Ado, then Roar.

Picking up on your earlier post, I do agree that we should reserve the
ligature Earth for the /3r/ sound, and use Ado + Roar in words like
"arrest."

Paul
